introduction: The following text is adapted from A Tale of Two Cities by Charles Dickens (1859). Dr. Manette is reflecting on his long imprisonment and the effect it has had on him.
text: Dr. Manette sat quietly in his chair, his thoughts drifting back to the years he had spent in the Bastille. <u>Those years had stripped him of his former identity, leaving him a shadow of the man he once was. The memories of his imprisonment were sharp, but they had also made him stronger, in a way he couldn’t fully explain.</u> He wasn’t the same, but perhaps that wasn’t a bad thing.
question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?
A: It highlights Dr. Manette’s acceptance of the changes that his imprisonment has brought him.
B: It suggests that Dr. Manette feels trapped by his memories of the past.
C: It emphasizes Dr. Manette's regret over the person he has become after his imprisonment.
D: It illustrates Dr. Manette’s struggle to reconcile his past identity with his present self.
explanation: Choice A is the best answer because the underlined portion reflects Dr. Manette’s recognition that his time in prison has changed him, but in a way that he views as not entirely negative. He has become stronger, despite the loss of his former self.Choice B is incorrect because the passage does not suggest Dr. Manette feels trapped by his memories but rather acknowledges the sharpness of his memories.Choice C is incorrect.
